text: Stratified survival curves great way visualize effect categorical variable, treatment status, survival time. easy produce, easy understand (done correctly) visually appealing. situation slightly complicated confounders exist need accounted . case, methods explicitly remove influence confounders need used estimate curves. Luckily, quite methods also associated R-packages implement directly, adjustedCurves package. many cases however, interested effect categorical variable. Instead want show effect continuous variable, example studying new biomarker predict certain disease. Currently, small amount research topic even less publicly available code. confounder-adjustment required, available code literature practically non-existent. contsurvplot tries fill gap providing multiple types plots visualize causal effect continuous variable time--event outcome. plots included rely previously fit model describes effect target variable time--event outcome. model used perform Direct Standardization estimate covariate-level-specific survival curves cumulative incidence functions (CIF). including confounders model, plots naturally adjusted confounders. vignette, showcase usage methods.

title: Visualizing the Causal Effect of a Continuous Variable on a Time-To-Event Outcome
text: First load required packages. seems like lot, required one plot . example utilize colon dataset included famous survival R-package. includes data 1858 patients study treating colon cancer using adjuvant chemotherapy. can obtain colon data using data() function. first rows dataset: exemplary purposes, suppose interested causal effect number lymph nodes detectable cancer (column nodes). semi-continuous variable , defined integers. however treat proper continuous variable , since makes difference examples. First, need model describing time--event outcome order make plots possible. , simply use cox-regression model, including covariates age, sex nodes independent variables: important use x=TRUE function call, otherwise won’t possible create needed estimates. including age sex, adjusting graphics variables. using standard summary method coxph model object, can take look estimated hazard-ratios: can see hazard-ratio target variable nodes approximately 1.091. Together small p-value, indicates survival probability patients decreases rising number affected lymph nodes. plausible (hardly shocking) result. bad hazard-ratio 1.091 exactly? trained statistician might problem interpreting number correctly, many medical scientists number might mean much. Appropriate visualizations key proper communication regression results. relative effect measures, hazard-ratio, inherently harder intrepret absolute effect measures, use latter. includes standard survival probability time \(t\).

title: Visualizing the Causal Effect of a Continuous Variable on a Time-To-Event Outcome
text: simplest plot survival probability specific point time function continuous variable. can done contsurvplot package using plot_surv_at_t function. example, following graph can produced using \(t = 1000\)  can make graph little interesting plotting survival probability multiple points time :  Although function easy produce understand, lacks information survival probability times shown. best use method specific (possibly pre-specified) times interest.
code: plot_surv_at_t(time="time",                status="status",                variable="nodes",                data=colon,                model=model,                t=1000) plot_surv_at_t(time="time",                status="status",                variable="nodes",                data=colon,                model=model,                t=c(100, 500, 1000, 1500, 2000))

title: Visualizing the Causal Effect of a Continuous Variable on a Time-To-Event Outcome
text: different kind statistic restricted mean survival time (RMST). defined area survival curve specific point \(\tau\) can interpreted mean survival time cohort interval \([0, \tau]\). taking whole integral, statistic technically takes whole survival curve specific interval account. However, still dependent \(\tau\). graph similar ones , using RSMT, can produced using plot_surv_rmst function:  show estimates change different values \(\tau\), can also supply multiple values yet produce multiple curves:
code: plot_surv_rmst(time="time",                status="status",                variable="nodes",                data=colon,                model=model,                tau=1000) plot_surv_rmst(time="time",                status="status",                variable="nodes",                data=colon,                model=model,                tau=c(500, 1000, 2000))

title: Visualizing the Causal Effect of a Continuous Variable on a Time-To-Event Outcome
text: restricted mean time lost (RMTL) closely related RMST. Instead integrating area survival curve, area cumulative incidence function (CIF) calculated. can useful multiple mutually exclusive event types, case cause-specific CIF can estimated, cause-specific survival curve. plot_surv_rmtl function can used purpose. functionality syntax plot_rmst function, show one plot multiple \(\tau\) values :  Since simple survival case one event type, equation \(F(t) = 1 - S(t)\) still holds, curves simply inverted.
code: plot_surv_rmtl(time="time",                status="status",                variable="nodes",                data=colon,                model=model,                tau=c(500, 1000, 2000))

title: Visualize the Effect of a Continuous Variable on a Time-To-Event Outcome
text: contsurvplot R-Package can used visualize causal effect continuous variable time--event outcome. includes multiple different plot types, survival area plots, contour plots, heatmaps, survival quantile plots . can adjusted confounders lot build options customize according users needs. Also, plot functions based ggplot2 package, allowing user use standard ggplot2 syntax customize plots .

code: library(devtools)  devtools::install_github("RobinDenz1/contsurvplot") library(remotes)  remotes::install_github("RobinDenz1/contsurvplot")

title: Visualize the Effect of a Continuous Variable on a Time-To-Event Outcome
text: two quick examples using colon dataset survival R-Package. Suppose want visualize effect number lymph nodes detectable cancer (column nodes) survival time. survival area plot can produced using following code:  Alternatively, can plot contour plot visualize effect:  can use simple plot median survival time function nodes:  examples can found documentation vignette.
code: library(contsurvplot) library(ggplot2) library(survival) library(riskRegression)  # load colon data data(cancer)  # fit cox model, adjusting for age and sex model <- coxph(Surv(time, status) ~ age + sex + nodes, data=colon, x=TRUE)  # plot survival area plot_surv_area(time="time",         status="status",         variable="nodes",         data=colon,         model=model) plot_surv_contour(time="time",           status="status",           variable="nodes",           data=colon,           model=model) plot_surv_quantiles(time="time",            status="status",            variable="nodes",            data=colon,            model=model,            p=0.5)

title: Calculate Causal Survival or Failure Probabilities for Levels of a Continuous Variable — curve_cont
code: if (FALSE) { library(riskRegression) library(survival)  # using data from the survival package data(nafld, package="survival")  # fit cox-model with age model <- coxph(Surv(futime, status) ~ age, data=nafld1, x=TRUE)  # estimate survival probability at some points in time, for # a range of age values plotdata <- curve_cont(data=nafld1,                        variable="age",                        model=model,                        horizon=seq(50, 80, 1),                        times=seq(0, 4000, 100))  # estimate cumulative incidences instead plotdata <- curve_cont(data=nafld1,                        variable="age",                        model=model,                        horizon=seq(50, 80, 1),                        times=seq(0, 4000, 100),                        cif=TRUE) }

title: Plot the Survival Curve or CIF Dependent on a Continuous Variable as a 3D Surface — plot_surv_3Dsurface
code: if (FALSE) { library(riskRegression) library(survival) library(splines) library(ggplot2) library(plotly)  # using data from the survival package data(nafld, package="survival")  # fit cox-model with age model <- coxph(Surv(futime, status) ~ age, data=nafld1, x=TRUE)  # plot effect of age on survival for ages 50 to 80 plot_surv_3Dsurface(time="futime",                     status="status",                     variable="age",                     data=nafld1,                     model=model,                     horizon=seq(50, 80, 0.5),                     interactive=FALSE)  # plot effect of age on survival using an interactive plot for ages 50 to 80 plot_surv_3Dsurface(time="futime",                     status="status",                     variable="age",                     data=nafld1,                     model=model,                     horizon=seq(50, 80, 0.5),                     interactive=TRUE)  ## showing non-linear effects  # fit cox-model with bmi modeled using B-Splines, # adjusting for age and sex model2 <- coxph(Surv(futime, status) ~ age + male + bs(bmi, df=5),                 data=nafld1, x=TRUE)  # plot effect of bmi on survival using normal plot plot_surv_3Dsurface(time="futime",                     status="status",                     variable="bmi",                     data=nafld1,                     model=model2,                     interactive=FALSE)  # plot effect of bmi on survival using interactive plot plot_surv_3Dsurface(time="futime",                     status="status",                     variable="bmi",                     data=nafld1,                     model=model2,                     interactive=TRUE) }
